posts.name: Brian Gray
posts.cooked: After using Lexan for years, we’re thinking about doing an inverted bellypan using 1/4" birch.  But how do we keep it from looking…um… woody?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Cleverly disguised as a responsible adult

posts.custom_user_title: Cleverly disguised as a responsible adult

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
Looks good to me

image 1028×705 186 KB

image 1028×705 186 KB

image 1028×705 186 KB

Sometimes making wood look less wood like doesn’t pay off in the long run. Anytime we’ve tried covering up wood with paint you get small chips and flakes on the edges and looks worse even with touchup.

Rattlecan spray paint is just fine for a quick one-night job if really don’t like the look of wood.

posts.name: Jim Forbes
posts.cooked:
We only have a couple, the best looking one was 2009, when we painted the wood robot and people asked us if it was powder coated aluminum

posts.name: Gdeaver
posts.cooked: Laminate a layer of carbon fiber on both sides. We have been doing this for years. Greatly stiffens 6mm Baltic Birch.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Now you need to post the REST of them. Start with 2001, go until the BeachBots stopped using wood bellypans. (That would be somewhere around 2019, IIRC…)

The key to having a nice wooden bellypan is to start with nice plywood. Then you sand it, maybe seal it a bit, and when you’re installing make sure to put the screws in properly. 6mm baltic birch plus some sand-and-seal, and if you’re concerned about strength glue another layer on top, should come out nicely.

posts.name: Andrew Milakovich
posts.cooked:
Second the spray paint option, turned out great on a dark belly pan in 2020. Never got to see how it held up in competition sadly
